conclusion: Consider the forces acting on the particle as it moves through the magnetic field and electric field.
The particle is moving in a straight line and is not affected by the gravitational force.
The only forces acting on the particle are the magnetic force and the electric force.
The magnetic force on the particle is given by the equation \( F_B = qvB \).
Since the particle is moving in a straight line, the magnetic force is perpendicular to the velocity.
The magnetic force is equal to the product of the magnetic induction strength and the velocity of the particle.
The electric force on the particle is given by the equation \( F_E = qEd \).
Since the electric force is perpendicular to the electric field.
The electric force is equal to the product of the electric field strength and the distance between the plates.
The particle is moving in a straight line and is not affected by the gravitational force.
The net force acting on the particle must be zero.
The net force is the sum of the magnetic force and the electric force.
Setting the net force equal to zero, we get \( qvB + qEd = 0 \).
Solving for \( v \), we get \( v = -\frac{qEd}{qB} = -\frac{Ed}{B} \).
The magnitude of the velocity of the particle when it is shot into point S is \( -\frac{Ed}{B} \).
